abstract: Venture capitalists in the tech industry are concerned about runaway valuations of some young companies, but are wary of referring to industry's current state as a 'bubble,' like that of the 1990s; valuations of companies have steadily been inflating, sign that investors are making decisions that are uncoupled from fundamentals of businesses they invest in, but analysts are quick to dispute idea that this has led to bubble.
lead_paragraph: The tech industry’s venture capitalists admit to a certain amount of “frothiness” in start-up investments, but they studiously avoid another word. Bubble.

headline.main: Overvalued in Silicon Valley, but Don’t Say ‘Tech Bubble’
headline.print_headline: Tech Investors See the Froth, but None Dare Call It a Bubble

snippet: The tech industry’s venture capitalists admit to a certain amount of “frothiness” in start-up investments, but they studiously avoid another word. Bubble.
